comments.body: Why is `third` here? I must be missing something :)

ClientAccessFactory is the first level.
ObjectMappingFactory depends on ClientAccessFactory and it's the second level.
BuilderFactory depends on ObjectMappingFactory, so I think it should be the third level.
yes, rings are `ClientAccessFactory -> ObjectMappingFactory -> BuilderFactory`, thanks for the comment fix
I want to understand the reason why stopping using pointer, though I don't think it matters since `Resources` only has 2 maps in it.
Because it used to be a struct, and it's not an interface. Pointer to an interface doesn't make as much sense as a pointer to a struct.
Describe `[]byte` in the Godoc here.
directions?

> directions?

connection info?  address, port, certs, etc
nvm, was thinking this should have been "direct" but I get it now.
I'm a little bit hesitant to use this lengthy generator name. Although this one will not be probably exposed to users.

> I'm a little bit hesitant to use this lengthy generator name. Although this one will not be probably exposed to users.

We get a release to change it if we don't like it.  If we expect these to take off (I still think its unlikely), we'll need a reasonable way to namespace them.

My main concern is when using `kubectl run` we advice users to use `--generator` flag to be sure this works consistently between versions. But I guess the current directions are to get rid of run and rather replace it with targeted `kubectl create` commands. That's why I guess I'm good with that.

comments.body: Why have these been added?

@deads2k originally `Factory` struct has these methods, and they are exported, so other packages can use. If we make `Factory` interface, and not add these methods to the interface definition, other packages which use this interface can not use theses methods anymore.
If these weren't exposed before, lets keep them hidden.  I don't think we want to encourage access patterns like this.
@deads2k actually these are methods of `Factory` struct before, and they are exported. The problem is why we add these methods as struct methods, and others as struct fields.
please remove/hide.  We don't want to the factory accepting the command.  We want specific structs passing the information we need and all of these look be net-new
Nice
The arg to this method is dead, but ripping it out requires considering how to handle the now-dead flag.  I'd like to do that separately.
nit: no empty line
This is not fatal anymore. I guess that's intentional.

> This is not fatal anymore. I guess that's intentional.

Yeah, it should never have been fatal.  It's useful to know that it failed (hence the message), but its not a thing that matters most of the time.  If it matters, you'll fail later.

Compare https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/32678. `/version` should be optional.
Also old servers don't have third party resources.
Is it worth to check for serverVersion being empty? Otherwise, this panics.
Should you rely on the server version to decide about this? Would it be possible to try to register the third-party resources and fallback on error?

Discovery information was incomplete before.  I agree that this will end up causing a problem when running against servers that either don't host `/version` or reflect their versions, not kube versions.

I'll open a followup issue.

comments.body: Shouldn't we sort this list and pick the oldest pod?

> Shouldn't we sort this list and pick the oldest pod?

I didn't want to change the order on the other callers.  If `kubectl logs` chooses one, the oldest one isn't likely to be the correct choice. You probably want to check things like status to find the most recent one that failed.  For attach, you want to find one that's running and probably the most recent one.

At any rate, I'm not convinced that sorting makes the behavior better.
Fair, I don't feel strong anyway
can you fix this to copy the passed in args (not mutate them), and just use `args[0]` directly instead of hard-coding `kubectl`?

I will look into switching to patch in a follow-up if that's ok

comments.body: Can you explain the differences between `MapBasedSelectorForObject` and `PodSelectorForObject` (why do we need to separate them)? Is it because `ParseLabels` in pkg/kubectl/generate.go can only recognize and convert labels/selectors like `app=nginx` to `map[string]string` but not those like `app in (nginx)`?
Yes exactly, that's the reason. And did not want to change the signature of that function.
If so do we need to support deployment for `PodSelectorForObject`? Do we need to support rc, pod, service for `MapBasedSelectorForObject`?

The idea is that, PodSelectorForObject() returns the stringified/serialized version of the pod selector no matter which object you give, provided the object has object.Spec.Selector field (that reminds me I should add ReplicaSet to this function as well in my other PR). MapBasedSelectorForObject() returns only the map[string]string component. And both of them do that consistently for all the objects as long as object.Spec.Selector field exists.
OK
bad rebase? Seems like this probably meant to be left alone.

- Pulled cache-dir up to be a flag, so clearing/expiring involves deleting that directory, or specifying an alternate directory.

Clayton Coleman | Lead Engineer, OpenShift
No error checking?
The experimental client failing to initialize is non-fatal. In clientSwaggerSchema we only use the experimentalClient if it is non-nil.
I vastly prefer this to looking up the flag from inside the function, but why would something with `validate == false` ever call the `Validator()` function?

Since `--validate` only makes sense for certain commands, I removed it from global flags, and therefore now this flag is in `cmd.Flags()` instead of `factory.flags`. This means to check the value of this flag, we should use `cmd.Flags().GetBool()` instead of `flags.Lookup()`. Passing the bool value here is better than passing `cmd`, imo. If `Validator()` is called with `validate == false`, `validation.NullSchema{}` will be returned.

> Since --validate only makes sense for certain commands, I removed it from global flags, and therefore now this flag is in cmd.Flags() instead of factory.flags. This means to check the value of this flag, we should use cmd.Flags().GetBool() instead of flags.Lookup(). Passing the bool value here is better than passing cmd, imo. If Validator() is called with validate == false, validation.NullSchema{} will be returned.

I think we talked passed each other.  I agree, this factorization is better than what previously existed.  My question is, if a caller has a value for `shouldValidate`, why wouldn't he do something like

```
if shouldValidate{
    f.Validator()
}
```

?
I see. The caller should only call when they should validate, and we don't need the `validation.NullSchema{}` in Validator.

Correction: the caller gets `schema` back from `Validator()` and sets the schema of resource builder. Therefore, it makes the code cleaner to always get a schema back, and inside `Validator()` we use `shouldValidate` to determine which schema (swagger or null) to be returned. 

The caller calls `Validator()` when `validate == false` because it still needs a schema.
This should be using the same pattern as the cache.
Is there a particular reason? I'd have to copy the code for the experimental client, and I don't think we'll have multiple versions.
See my other comment above - you can't fail in Factory initialization by reading the config.

comments.body: You can't do this here - it fails too early (when factory is created, not when methods on factory are called).  Initialization like this should always be under a Factory method (so that errors are returned when the user asks for clients, NOT when the user asks for a factory (clients are not required to be valid for all command types).

Factory creation is successful regardless of whether this succeeds. The error is returned when the user asks for a experimental client. I also don't see anywhere where we manipulate the clientConfig so this should have the same behavior.
Client config can fail - it can fail BEFORE the help message runs.  So you can't allow CLI to have Factory creation fail based on a bad config - it has to fail later.

Maybe I'm not seeing it, but how does Factory creation fail? There is no if err != nil { return err } statement here. We are keeping the error and returning it when an experimental client is requested, not when the factory is created.

If client config panic's then that changes things, but it really should not panic.

Ok, sorry.  I still don't like init'ing it up front but I can live with
that particular part for now.

Another reason in general I don't like doing it up front is that it will
parse the CA and possibly the key - I don't know how expensive that is but
I assume it's not free.  If you had code that didn't call the experimental
client you'd still pay the cost.
